sage.scene

Class TriMesh

  • java.lang.Object
    • sage.scene.SceneNode
      • sage.scene.Leaf
        • sage.scene.TriMesh
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    Model3DTriMesh, Pyramid, Quad, TerrainBlock

    public class TriMesh
extends Leaf
    TriMesh defines a Leaf consisting of a geometric object made up of triangles defined by a collection of vertices, together with attributes associated with the vertices.

    Each TriMesh object contains a collection of FloatBuffers, one for each of the following:

    • vertex data (X,Y,Z triples),
    • per-vertex color values (R,G,B,A quadruples),
    • per-vertex normals (U,V,N triples),
    • per-vertex texture coordinates (S,T tuples)
    Note that a TriMesh only supports 3D (X,Y,Z) vertex geometry and 2D (S,T) texturing.

    Each FloatBuffer is tightly packed (for example, the first three floats in the vertex data buffer, representing the X, Y, Z coordinates of the first vertex, are immediately followed in the buffer by the three floats representing the X, Y, Z coordinates of another vertex.

    In addition to the above, each TriMesh also contains an IntBuffer holding indexes into the FloatBuffers defined above. Each consecutive index value references one of the vertices or corresponding vertex attributes making up a triangle. For example, the first three entries in the index buffer contains the numbers of the vertex buffer entries representing the first three triangle vertices; those same three index values also point to the locations in the attribute buffers containing the corresponding attributes (e.g. color, normal, etc.) of the three triangle vertices. In other words, each consecutive set of three entries in the index buffer defines one face (triangle) of the TriMesh. Note that index values reference logical structures in the vertex/normal/texture/color buffers, not array locations. For example, an index value of 2 refers to vertex #2, not element [2] in the vertex FloatBuffer. Since each vertex is comprised of 3 floats, index 2 actually refers to elements [6], [7], and [8] in the vertex buffer (an index value of 0 refers to vertex buffer elements [0], [1], and [2], etc.)

    Each TriMesh also contains an ArrayList of Materials defining the material associated with each face (triangle) of the TriMesh (if any materials were defined when the Trimesh was created), along with an IntBuffer containing indices into the face materials. Each entry in the face materials index buffer corresponds to one face (triangle) as defined by the Trimesh's main index buffer, and points to the entry in the face material array for that triangle. The specified entry in the face material array is a Material which defines the material attributes for that triangle, including the name of any texture-map file defined for the triangle face.

    To render (draw) a TriMesh object, a renderer would loop through the TriMesh's index buffer, using each consecutive set of three index values to access a single triangle's geometric, normal, and texture coordinate data from the corresponding buffers, while also using the corresponding entry in the face material index buffer to access the material attached to the triangle. Note that each entry in the vertex, normal, texture, and etc. arrays is comprised of multiple floats as described above; code which renders the TriMesh object must take these offsets in to account. If the material contains a texture map file name, the rendering code is also responsible for constructing a texture object from the specified file and arranging that the texture is bound and enabled and that the proper texture coordinates are output to the underlying graphics API. (See the JOGL Texture and TextureIO classes for additional information on using textures.) (See also the size parameter of the OpenGL glVertexPointer() method.)

    Author:
    John Clevenger, based on a similar set of classes in jMonkeyEngine.
    See Also:
    Texture, TextureIO, Material, OBJMaterial, OBJLoader

    • Constructor Detail

      • TriMesh

        public TriMesh()
        Constructs a new TriMesh with a default name and other parameters as specified by TriMesh(String). Be sure to observe the note in that constructor regarding the usefulness of constructing TriMesh objects without specifying vertex values.

      • TriMesh

        public TriMesh(java.lang.String name)
        Constructs a new TriMesh object with the specified name and having empty (null) vertex, attribute, and index data. Note that it's not normally very useful to construct a TriMesh with null vertices; applications which invoke this constructor should take care to subsequently define vertices for the TriMesh using setVertexBuffer(FloatBuffer)).

      • TriMesh

        public TriMesh(java.lang.String name,
               java.nio.FloatBuffer vertices,
               java.nio.FloatBuffer normals,
               java.nio.FloatBuffer colors,
               java.nio.FloatBuffer texCoords,
               java.nio.IntBuffer indexes)
        Constructs a new TriMesh object containing the specified vertex, attribute, and index data. Unneeded parameters (e.g. normals, colors, and/or texCoords may be null; however, it's not normally very useful to construct a TriMesh with null vertices.
        Parameters:
        vertices - - the X,Y,Z values for points that make up the geometry.
        normals - - the U,V,N normals of each vertex.
        colors - - the R,G,B,A colors of each vertex.
        texCoords - - the (S,T) texture coordinates of the geometry
        indexes - - the integer indices into the vertices

      • TriMesh

        public TriMesh(java.lang.String name,
               java.nio.FloatBuffer vertices,
               java.nio.FloatBuffer normals,
               java.nio.FloatBuffer colors,
               java.nio.FloatBuffer texCoords)
        Constructs a new TriMesh object containing the given vertex, normal, color and texture information and with a default index buffer such that each index value references the corresponding vertex in the input vertices buffer. Unneeded parameters (e.g. normals, colors, and/or texCoords may be null (however, it's not normally very useful to construct a TriMesh with null vertices).

        The default index buffer is such that the contents of index element [0]=0, the contents of index element [1]=1, etc..

        Parameters:
        vertices - - the X,Y,Z values for the vertices making up the mesh.
        normals - - the normals of each vertex.
        colors - - the colors of each vertex.
        texCoords - - the texture coordinates for each vertex

    • Method Detail

      • updateLocalBound

        public void updateLocalBound()
        updateLocalBound updates the local-space BoundingVolume associated with this TriMesh Leaf object so that the BoundingVolume contains the currently-defined TriMesh vertices. If the TriMesh currently has no BoundingVolume then a BoundingSphere is created; otherwise, the current BoundingVolume type is updated.
        Specified by:
        updateLocalBound in class Leaf

      • draw

        public void draw(IRenderer r)
        draw() invokes predraw() for this Leaf, invokes the specified IRenderer to draw the Leaf, then invokes postdraw() for this Leaf.
        Specified by:
        draw in class Leaf
        Parameters:
        r - - the IRenderer to be used to draw this Leaf.
        See Also:
        predraw(IRenderer), postdraw(IRenderer)

      • getVertexBuffer

        public java.nio.FloatBuffer getVertexBuffer()
        Returns the FloatBuffer that contains this TriMesh's vertex information.
        Returns:
        the vertex data FloatBuffer

      • setVertexBuffer

        public void setVertexBuffer(java.nio.FloatBuffer vertBuf)
        Sets the buffer containing this TriMesh's vertices to the specified FloatBuffer, which is expected to consist of groups of three floats (x, y and z) packed in consecutive buffer locations. If the received FloatBuffer is not null, the number of vertices contained in the FloatBuffer is checked to insure it is an even multiple of three (each vertex must contain exactly X,Y and Z); if not, a RuntimeException is thrown.

        If a valid vertex buffer is supplied, then setVertexBuffer() also invokes updateLocalBound() to insure that the local bounding volume matches the new vertex set.

        Parameters:
        vertBuf - the new vertex buffer.

      • getNormalBuffer

        public java.nio.FloatBuffer getNormalBuffer()
        Returns the FloatBuffer containing this TriMesh's vertex normal information.
        Returns:
        the float buffer containing the vertex normal information.

      • setFaceMaterials

        public void setFaceMaterials(java.util.ArrayList<Material> faceMaterials)
        setFaceMaterials sets the array of face materials in this TriMesh to the specified array of Materials. The order of the materials in the specified array is assumed to correspond to the faces (triangles) of the TriMesh as defined by the index buffer of the TriMesh.
        Parameters:
        faceMaterials - the materials for each face (triangle)

      • getFaceMaterials

        public java.util.ArrayList<Material> getFaceMaterials()
        getFaceMaterials returns the ArrayList holding the Materials associated with the faces (triangles) of this TriMesh.
        Returns:
        - the face material array for the TriMesh

      • setFaceMaterialIndices

        public void setFaceMaterialIndices(java.nio.IntBuffer faceMaterialIndexBuffer)
        setFaceMaterialIndices sets the buffer of face material indices in this TriMesh to the specified IntBuffer. Each face material index points to a Material in the face material array of the TriMesh. The order of the face material indices should correspond to the order of faces (triangles) in the index buffer of the TriMesh (that is, each set of three indices in the index buffer defines one triangle, and each individual face material index identifies the material which should be applied to that triangle.
        Parameters:
        faceMaterialIndexBuffer - the material indices for each face

      • getFaceMaterialIndices

        public java.nio.IntBuffer getFaceMaterialIndices()
        getFaceMaterials returns the ArrayList holding the Materials associated with the faces (triangles) of this TriMesh.
        Returns:
        - the face material array for the TriMesh

      • predraw

        public boolean predraw(IRenderer r)
        This method is called by draw(IRenderer) prior to invoking the renderer to draw this TriMesh; it forces the IRenderer.RENDER_METHOD of the renderer to become IRenderer.RENDER_METHOD.VERTEX_ARRAY. The current IRenderer.RENDER_METHOD of the renderer is saved prior to being changed.

        To suppress this behavior, extend TriMesh and override both predraw() (to do nothing but return true) and postdraw() to do nothing.

        Overrides:
        predraw in class Leaf
        Parameters:
        r - - the IRenderer which will ultimately be used to draw this Leaf.

      • postdraw

        public void postdraw(IRenderer r)
        This method is called by draw(IRenderer) after the call to the renderer's draw() method in draw(IRenderer) returns; it restores the RenderMethod of the renderer to its former (saved) state.

        To suppress this behavior, extend TriMesh and override both predraw() (to do nothing but return true) and postdraw() to do nothing.

        Overrides:
        postdraw in class Leaf
        Parameters:
        r - - the IRenderer which was used to draw this Leaf.
